title: French Open 2025 Day One Recap
description: The 2025 French Open kicked off on Sunday but was blighted by intermittent rain, causing several stoppages on the outside courts. In the men‚Äôs draw, 20 main draw matches were played, all from the bottom half. The rest of the first-round matches will be played on Monday and Tuesday. While none of the highly fancied ‚Ä¶
author: Jonathan
excerpt: The 2025 French Open kicked off on Sunday but was blighted by intermittent rain, causing several stoppages on the outside courts. In the men's draw, 20 main draw matches were played, all from the bott
text: The 2025 French Open kicked off on Sunday but was blighted by intermittent rain, causing several stoppages on the outside courts. In the men‚Äôs draw, 20 main draw matches were played, all from the bottom half. The rest of the first-round matches will be played on Monday and Tuesday. While none of the highly fancied players were in action, several with a puncher‚Äôs chance featured, with Lorenzo Musetti and Tommy Paul, the two highest seeds in action, both progressing. The former maintained his excellent form during the clay court swing by brushing aside Yannick Hanfmann. At the same time, Tommy Paul overcame dropping the first set to backhand specialist Elmer Moller before cruising in four. Brandom Nakashima (28) and Tomas Machac (21) were the highest-profile casualties. Both were predictable, as Nakashima faced clay court specialist Navone, while Machac seems incapable of finishing a match lately. In the night session, Ben Shelton came through in five sets against Lorenzo Sonego in a match that ended past midnight and lasted 3 hours. Outside of match play, the day started with a tribute to Rafael Nadal, the 14-time champion who retired last year. Fans donned thousands of brick-red ‚ÄúMerci Rafa‚Äù T-shirts, transforming the stands while the ceremony unveiled a permanent tribute: his footprint embedded in the clay, Rafa was joined by Novak Djokovic, Andy Murray, and Roger Federer in a Big Four reunion. Or Big 3 plus one if you preferü§£, and it‚Äôs good to see those guys together after providing fans with some great matches over the last 20 years. Full results, recap and highlights below. Day One French Open 2025 Round of 128 Results Winner Loser Scoreline Lorenzo Musetti (8) Yannick Hanfmann (Q) 7-5 6-2 6-0 Daniel Elahi Galan (LL) Valentin Royer (WC) 7-6(6) 6-3 3-6 6-7(4) 7-5 Reilly Opelka Rinky Hijikata 1-6 6-3 7-5 7-6(3) Mariano Navone Brandon Nakashima (28) 7-6(2) 4-6 6-1 6-2 Quentin Halys Tomas Machac (21) 7-6(4) 4-1 (RET) Emilio Nava Botic van de Zandschulp 6-2 7-5 7-5 Frances Tiafoe (15) Roman Safiullin 6-4 7-5 6-4 Pablo Carreno Busta Francisco Comesana 6-2 7-6(3) 7-5 Jensen Brooksby Jaime Faria 6-1 3-6 6-3 6-2 Juan Manuel Cerundolo (Q) Alex Michelsen (32) 6-3 6-2 6-4 Hamad Medjedovic Kamil Majchrzak 6-3 6-3 7-6(2) Vit Kopriva Thiago Monteiro 6-4 6-3 4-6 6-7(6) 6-1 Nuno Borges Kyrian Jacquet (Q) 3-6 6-7(3) 6-4 6-3 6-3 Marton Fucsovics Tristan Schoolkate (WC) 6-4 6-2 6-2 Tommy Paul (12) Elmer Moller (LL) 6-7(5) 6-2 6-3 6-1 Ben Shelton (13) Lorenzo Sonego 6-4 4-6 3-6 6-2 6-3 Matteo Gigante (Q) Benjamin Hassan (Q) 6-4 6-2 6-0 Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard (31) Zizou Bergs 4-6 6-3 7-6(5) 6-4 Damir Dzhumur Thiago Augustin Tirante (LL) 3-6 6-4 6-3 7-5 Fabian Marozsan Luca Nardi 6-2 6-3 7-6(3) Recap of the Day Lorenzo Musetti (8) def. Yannick Hanfmann (Q) 7-5, 6-2, 6-0 Lorenzo Musetti kicked off his 2025 Roland Garros campaign with a commanding 7-5, 6-2, 6-0 victory over qualifier Yannick Hanfmann on Court Philippe-Chatrier. While he hasn‚Äôt been prominent recently, Hanfmann is a competent clay courter. Despite offering resistance in a tough first set, he was no match for Musetti, who dominated throughout. Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard (31) def. Zizou Bergs 4-6, 6-3, 7-6(5), 6-4 French No. 31 seed Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard gave the fans on Court Suzanne Lenglen something to shout about with a three-hour, 18-minute thriller against Zizou Bergs. The 6‚Äô8‚Äù Lyon native stared down a 0/5 deficit in the third-set tiebreak, only to reel off a seven-point run under the closed roof. Two aces, a stunning passing shot, and Bergs‚Äô untimely double fault flipped the script. Mpetshi Perricard, fresh from winning the Bordeaux Challenger after struggling on tour this season, wobbled when serving for the match at 5-3 in the fourth but broke back to seal it, firing 12 aces to secure his spot in round 2. Tommy Paul (12) def. Elmer Moller (LL) 6-7(5), 6-2, 6-3, 6-1 American No. 12 seed Tommy Paul shook off a sluggish start to overpower lucky loser Elmer Moller in four sets. Moller nabbed the first set in a tiebreak, but Paul, who impressed me with his clay game in Rome, flipped the switch, cruising through the next three sets with his trademark athleticism. Paul now faces Marton Fucsovics which could be interesting as their head-to-head is tied at 2-2. Mariano Navone def. Brandon Nakashima (28) 7-6(2), 4-6, 6-1, 6-2 World No. 98 Mariano Navone downed No. 28 seed Brandon Nakashima in four sets. This was probably the upset most people would have predicted, as the Argentine‚Äôs relentless topspin and clay-court craft make him a formidable opponent here, especially for those who aren‚Äôt as comfortable on the surface. Quentin Halys def. Tomas Machac (21) 7-6(4), 4-1 (ret.) Frenchman Quentin Halys advanced to the second round after No. 21 seed Tomas Machac retired at 7-6(4), 4-1 down. Machac, struggling with a lower back issue, called for a medical timeout in the second set. Physio work focused on his waist area, and he retired after Halys broke to lead 4-1. The Czech seems to retire virtually every other match, and since last year‚Äôs US Open, he‚Äôs done so 8 times, this time his second in his many weeks after Geneva. Strangely, retirements never seem to cause any missed events or prolonged spells on the sidelines, so who knows what is happening there? Highlights French Open 2025 Day Two Round of 128 Matches Top Half Jannik Sinner (1) vs Arthur Rinderknech Terence Atmane vs Richard Gasquet Jiri Lehecka vs Jordan Thompson Pablo Llamas Ruiz vs Alejandro Davidovich Fokina (26) Camilo Ugo Carabelli vs Jaume Munar Nicolas Jarry vs Arthur Fils (14) Francisco Cerundolo (18) vs Gabriel Diallo Marcos Giron vs Tallon Griekspoor Jacob Fearnley vs Stan Wawrinka Christopher O‚ÄôConnell vs Ugo Humbert (22) Denis Shapovalov (27) vs Pedro Mart√≠nez Filip Misolic vs Yibing Bu Bottom Half Miomir Kecmanovic vs Sebasti√°n B√°ez Luciano Darderi vs Sebastian Korda (23) Daniel Altmaier vs Taylor Fritz (4) Casper Ruud (7) vs Albert Ramos Vi√±olas Alejandro Tabilo vs Arthur Cazaux Yoshihito Nishioka vs Alexei Popyrin (25) Roberto Bautista Agut vs Holger Rune (10) Hugo Gaston vs Ugo Blanchet Tom√°s Mart√≠n Etcheverry vs Stefanos Tsitsipas (20) Karen Khachanov vs Aleksandar Vukic Stefan Ofner vs Jan-Lennard Struff Giulio Zeppieri vs Carlos Alcaraz (2) Follow Us Editor of Perfect Tennis and a big fan of Roger Federer, I've spent countless hours watching and analysing his matches. Alongside playing the sport, I also enjoy writing about the tour, rackets, strings, and the technicalities of the game. Whether it's breaking down the latest tournament results or discussing the latest gear innovations, I'm always eager to share my insights with fellow tennis enthusiasts.
html:
The 2025 French Open kicked off on Sunday but was blighted by intermittent rain, causing several stoppages on the outside courts.

In the men‚Äôs draw, 20 main draw matches were played, all from the bottom half. The rest of the first-round matches will be played on Monday and Tuesday.

While none of the highly fancied players were in action, several with a puncher‚Äôs chance featured, with Lorenzo Musetti and Tommy Paul, the two highest seeds in action, both progressing.

The former maintained his excellent form during the clay court swing by brushing aside Yannick Hanfmann. At the same time, Tommy Paul overcame dropping the first set to backhand specialist Elmer Moller before cruising in four.

Brandom Nakashima (28) and Tomas Machac (21) were the highest-profile casualties. Both were predictable, as Nakashima faced clay court specialist Navone, while Machac seems incapable of finishing a match lately.

In the night session, Ben Shelton came through in five sets against Lorenzo Sonego in a match that ended past midnight and lasted 3 hours.

Outside of match play, the day started with a tribute to Rafael Nadal, the 14-time champion who retired last year.

Fans donned thousands of brick-red ‚ÄúMerci Rafa‚Äù T-shirts, transforming the stands while the ceremony unveiled a permanent tribute: his footprint embedded in the clay,

Rafa was joined by Novak Djokovic, Andy Murray, and Roger Federer in a Big Four reunion. Or Big 3 plus one if you preferü§£, and it‚Äôs good to see those guys together after providing fans with some great matches over the last 20 years.

Full results, recap and highlights below.

Day One French Open 2025 Round of 128 Results

Winner Loser Scoreline
Lorenzo Musetti (8) Yannick Hanfmann (Q) 7-5 6-2 6-0
Daniel Elahi Galan (LL) Valentin Royer (WC) 7-6(6) 6-3 3-6 6-7(4) 7-5
Reilly Opelka Rinky Hijikata 1-6 6-3 7-5 7-6(3)
Mariano Navone Brandon Nakashima (28) 7-6(2) 4-6 6-1 6-2
Quentin Halys Tomas Machac (21) 7-6(4) 4-1 (RET)
Emilio Nava Botic van de Zandschulp 6-2 7-5 7-5
Frances Tiafoe (15) Roman Safiullin 6-4 7-5 6-4
Pablo Carreno Busta Francisco Comesana 6-2 7-6(3) 7-5
Jensen Brooksby Jaime Faria 6-1 3-6 6-3 6-2
Juan Manuel Cerundolo (Q) Alex Michelsen (32) 6-3 6-2 6-4
Hamad Medjedovic Kamil Majchrzak 6-3 6-3 7-6(2)
Vit Kopriva Thiago Monteiro 6-4 6-3 4-6 6-7(6) 6-1
Nuno Borges Kyrian Jacquet (Q) 3-6 6-7(3) 6-4 6-3 6-3
Marton Fucsovics Tristan Schoolkate (WC) 6-4 6-2 6-2
Tommy Paul (12) Elmer Moller (LL) 6-7(5) 6-2 6-3 6-1
Ben Shelton (13) Lorenzo Sonego 6-4 4-6 3-6 6-2 6-3
Matteo Gigante (Q) Benjamin Hassan (Q) 6-4 6-2 6-0
Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard (31) Zizou Bergs 4-6 6-3 7-6(5) 6-4
Damir Dzhumur Thiago Augustin Tirante (LL) 3-6 6-4 6-3 7-5
Fabian Marozsan Luca Nardi 6-2 6-3 7-6(3)

Recap of the Day

Lorenzo Musetti (8) def. Yannick Hanfmann (Q) 7-5, 6-2, 6-0

Lorenzo Musetti kicked off his 2025 Roland Garros campaign with a commanding 7-5, 6-2, 6-0 victory over qualifier Yannick Hanfmann on Court Philippe-Chatrier.

While he hasn‚Äôt been prominent recently, Hanfmann is a competent clay courter. Despite offering resistance in a tough first set, he was no match for Musetti, who dominated throughout.

Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard (31) def. Zizou Bergs 4-6, 6-3, 7-6(5), 6-4

French No. 31 seed Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard gave the fans on Court Suzanne Lenglen something to shout about with a three-hour, 18-minute thriller against Zizou Bergs.

The 6‚Äô8‚Äù Lyon native stared down a 0/5 deficit in the third-set tiebreak, only to reel off a seven-point run under the closed roof.

Two aces, a stunning passing shot, and Bergs‚Äô untimely double fault flipped the script. Mpetshi Perricard, fresh from winning the Bordeaux Challenger after struggling on tour this season, wobbled when serving for the match at 5-3 in the fourth but broke back to seal it, firing 12 aces to secure his spot in round 2.

Tommy Paul (12) def. Elmer Moller (LL) 6-7(5), 6-2, 6-3, 6-1

American No. 12 seed Tommy Paul shook off a sluggish start to overpower lucky loser Elmer Moller in four sets.

Moller nabbed the first set in a tiebreak, but Paul, who impressed me with his clay game in Rome, flipped the switch, cruising through the next three sets with his trademark athleticism. Paul now faces Marton Fucsovics which could be interesting as their head-to-head is tied at 2-2.

Mariano Navone def. Brandon Nakashima (28) 7-6(2), 4-6, 6-1, 6-2

World No. 98 Mariano Navone downed No. 28 seed Brandon Nakashima in four sets. This was probably the upset most people would have predicted, as the Argentine‚Äôs relentless topspin and clay-court craft make him a formidable opponent here, especially for those who aren‚Äôt as comfortable on the surface.

Quentin Halys def. Tomas Machac (21) 7-6(4), 4-1 (ret.)

Frenchman Quentin Halys advanced to the second round after No. 21 seed Tomas Machac retired at 7-6(4), 4-1 down.

Machac, struggling with a lower back issue, called for a medical timeout in the second set. Physio work focused on his waist area, and he retired after Halys broke to lead 4-1.

The Czech seems to retire virtually every other match, and since last year‚Äôs US Open, he‚Äôs done so 8 times, this time his second in his many weeks after Geneva.

Strangely, retirements never seem to cause any missed events or prolonged spells on the sidelines, so who knows what is happening there?

Editor of Perfect Tennis and a big fan of Roger Federer, I've spent countless hours watching and analysing his matches. Alongside playing the sport, I also enjoy writing about the tour, rackets, strings, and the technicalities of the game. Whether it's breaking down the latest tournament results or discussing the latest gear innovations, I'm always eager to share my insights with fellow tennis enthusiasts.
